SCIENTISTS ARE DISPUTING THE FATE OF THE GRIZZLY 

  
 (ATTN: Texas, Mont.)   (The Science Times)  
(mk) 
 By JIM ROBBINS   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. _ A new report by two respected
wildlife biologists warns that the number of grizzly bears in and
around Yellowstone National Park may be much lower than previous
estimates.

   Moreover, one of the report's authors, David Mattson, a wildlife
biologist with the U.S. Geological Survey Biological Resources
Division, warns that the outlook for critical elements of grizzly
bear habitat, including whitebark pine nuts, is poor. ``The odds
are not good that we will see a stable to increasing population of
bears over the next 100 years,'' Mattson said in an interview.

   The report, which will be published this year in the journal
Ecology, is controversial, because it runs contrary to the widely
accepted belief that grizzly bear numbers in the park have
increased since the bear was listed as threatened under the
Endangered Species Act in 1975. And it comes at a time when the
Fish and Wildlife Service says the population is healthy enough to
begin the process of removing the bear from the list of threatened
species.

   Mattson began collecting data for the report in 1979. He and his
co-author, Craig Pease, a zoologist at the University of Texas,
have spent the last five years analyzing data. Using a counting
method that differs from past studies, they concluded there has
been little gain in total bear numbers in the last 20 years.

   ``We haven't had as much of an increase in the population as
many people would like to think,'' Mattson said. He said that in
1975 ``the best guess is there were something in excess of 300
bears.''

   ``At this point,'' he continued, ``we still have something in
excess of 300, perhaps as many as 400.'' Further, he said, any
increases in the population are the result of fluctuations in food
supply and not management of the population, placing the future
further in doubt.

   Mattson said his method does not rely on random sampling, as
past models have.

   But Chris Servheen, the Grizzly Bear Recovery coordinator for
the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in Missoula, Mont., said the
numbers are ``totally wrong.''

   ``There are between 400 and 500 bears in the system,'' he said,
``and we're seeing them in places we've never seen them.

   ``Things are going well now and we should take advantage of
that'' by removing the grizzly from the threatened list, he added.
``If all goes well, we'll propose a status change next year.''

   Some environmentalists fear removing the bear from the list
would offer it less protection, allowing, for example, more logging
and oil and gas development on federal land.

   Servheen, who predicts the bear could be removed from the list
by the year 2000, expects to release a draft of a document this
fall that will spell out how the grizzly will be managed by
Montana, Wyoming and Idaho once the bear is off the list.

   A battle is expected because the bear is one of the most
charismatic animals in the American West, and it arouses fierce
emotions on both sides of the issue. ``De-listing is premature,''
said Louisa Wilcox, a coordinator of the Sierra Club Grizzly Bear
Ecosystem Project. ``It's going to be a classic Yellowstone
knock-down, drag-out fight.''

   At the core of the debate are the numbers. Grizzly bears are
secretive and unpredictable, making a truly random sample extremely
difficult. Complicating the issue further is the fact that the
greater Yellowstone ecosystem is an ecological ``island'' with no
link to other grizzly bear populations. And there are many opinions
on how many bears are necessary to assure long-term survival.

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   It is not the present population level alone that concern
Mattson. The outlook for critical elements of the bear's habitat is
poor on almost every count, he said.

   Whitebark pines are the cause of most concern. Not only are the
nuts from these trees a critical fall food for the bears, but they
draw the bears to higher elevations and keep them in these remote
places, away from people. Conflicts between bears and people are
the leading cause of bear mortality in the Yellowstone ecosystem,
and there is a direct correlation between bad pine nut crops and
mortality rates, Mattson said.

   A disease called blister rust, which kills whitebark pines, has
made its way into areas north and west of Yellowstone, destroying
most of the trees. At the same time, some studies indicate that
global warming is causing the range of the pines to shrink.
Moreover, Yellowstone lost roughly 27 percent of its whitebark
pines in the 1988 fires, and the trees will take about 100 years to
replace.

   Global warming may also affect another prime food source, the
army cutworm moth. These moths feed on the nectar of high altitude
flowers at night. During the day, grizzlies find them under the
rocks in talus slopes. Biologists have seen as many as 50 bears
eating moths at one time. Alpine areas are sensitive to global
warming, and there is concern the moth's food source could
disappear.

   The shooting of hundreds of bison outside the park by Montana
livestock officials could also have an impact on bears. The state
fears that the bison harbor a disease that could be passed on to
cattle, and hauls the carcasses away, effectively removing a
critical source of protein.

   Damage to the fishery in Yellowstone Lake could also affect the
bear. Lake trout were discovered in the lake in 1994, probably
illegally introduced by fishermen. The huge fish prey on the
cutthroat population which spawns in the lake's tributaries where
as many as 30 or 40 bears may feed on them. Lake trout spawn in
deep water in the lake, and therefore don't provide food for the
bears.

   Habitat loss may be the single biggest threat to the grizzly.
The Yellowstone and Grand Teton parks make up only half of the 6
million-acre grizzly bear ecosystem. In the mix of other land
ownership there are large tracts of private property. Some counties
around the park are among the fastest growing in the country. Farms
and homes can attract bears with garbage and dog food, and when a
bear becomes habituated, or loses its fear of humans, it often
needs to be moved out of the ecosystem or ends up being shot. Elk
hunters who find a grizzly, and shoot it in self-defense, also
account for a large share of grizzly deaths.

   Servheen believes that Mattson and environmental groups opposed
to removing the bears from the list are exaggerating possible
threats to food supplies.

   ``He's saying there might be declines, and there might be,''
said Servheen. ``We'll monitor all these foods and have a response
protocol.''

   Even if the bear is taken off the list, Servheen said, the three
states around the park, the Park Service and the Forest Service
must agree to a plan to protect the bear. If numbers drop or a food
source seems imperiled, the bear can be placed back on the list.

   ``There's a misperception that de-listing means there's n open
season, with timber cutting and oil drilling in the forests around
the park,'' Servheen said. ``That's far from the case.''
